member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.JsonKey
member.summary:
A struct optimized to store integers, strings or GUID's used for entity identifiers.
E.g. 123, "123", "article" or "550e8400-e29b-11d4-a716-446655440000"
Encoding of integers can by numbers e.g. 123 or strings e.g. "123".
is used within the library for processing arbitrary entity identifiers.
member.remarks:
The optimization goals are:
- avoid heap allocations for the types mentioned above.
- providing a performant lookup when used as key in a or
Integers and GUID's are stored inside the struct. Strings with length less than 16 characters are also stored inside the struct to avoid heap allocations.
A can also represents a null value. It can be tested using .
Size of is 24 bytes

members.member:
Store either on of the objects below
null - a null reference
- an value
- a value
- a short string with length less than 16 bytes encoded a UTF-8
instance - an arbitrary string instance with length greater 15 bytes

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.JsonKey.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary:
Calling this constructor should be the last option as it may force a string creation.
Use alternative constructors if using a specific key type like or .

instances contain immutable JSON values.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.ShortString
member.summary:
A struct optimized to store strings with the focus on minimizing memory allocations
In contrast to it supports to check strings with
It is intended to be used for stable and descriptive names like: database, container, message, command, user, client and group names.
is optimized to enable filtering names by using a prefix - e.g. "std.*" used for authorization and subscriptions filters.
member.remarks:
The main optimization goal is to avoid string allocations.
Strings with length less than 16 characters are stored inside the struct to avoid heap allocations.
A can also represents a null value. It can be tested using .
Size of is 24 bytes

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Mapper.Map.TypeMapper`1.Copy(`0,`0@)
member.summary:
Derived 's where TVal is a reference type must override this method.
The dst parameter can be default (null if TVal is a reference type). Two cases:
If TVal is reference type the called method create and assign an instance.
If TVal is a value type the called method ignore its value and assign src to dst.

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Mapper.Map.TypeMapper`1.InitTypeMapper(Friflo.Json.Fliox.Mapper.TypeStore)
member.summary:
Need to be overridden, in case the derived support 's as fields or elements returning a .
In this case is used to map a to a required by calling and storing the returned reference also in the created instance.
This enables deferred initialization of TypeMapper to support circular type dependencies. The goal is to support also type hierarchies without a 'directed acyclic graph' (DAG) of type dependencies.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.Definition.TypeDef
member.summary:
Declare the shape of a specific type within a .
If is true the type is the root type of a database schema.
In this each field in represents a database container / table.
member.remarks: Note: Instances of including its fields are immutable.

member.name: P:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.Definition.TypeDef.Namespace
member.summary:
Namespace of a type. Depending on the generated language / schema is has the following meaning:
The of a in C#
The module (file) in Typescript (Javascript)
The schema file in JSON Schema
The package folder in Java
The package declaration in Kotlin

member.name: P:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.Definition.TypeDef.Path
member.summary:
The path of the file containing the generated type. It is set by .
In Typescript or JSON Schema a file can contain multiple types. These types have the same file and the same .
In Java each type require its own file. The is the Java package name which can be used by multiple types. But each type has its individual file .

members.member: The class this type extends. In other words its base or parent class.
If is true it has

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.Definition.FieldDef
member.summary:
The type definition of field (also named property) in a . E.g. a scalar type like boolean, int, float, double, DateTime, Guid, BigInteger or string or a complex type like an array, a map (= Dictionary) or a class. Fields also have a modifier to specify if a field is required or optional.
Within a database schema every table / container has a primary key exposed by the .

members.member: if is true contains the element type.
if is true contains the value type.
See

member.summary: is used to specify the interface of a command (= RPC) within a service. The structure of a command consists of its its command type and its command type. The command type specify the parameters and when a command is executed it returns an object of the given type.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.Definition.TypeSchema
member.summary: is an abstraction of an entire type system / database schema used for code generation and JSON payload validation like JSON Schema.
member.remarks:
The enables:
Simplify implementation of code generators as its API is tailored towards retrieving type information by simple getters using , , and .
Write code generators independent from the specific used like or .
Enable implementation of being independent from a specific like or .
Resolving all type references by 's defined in a type system / schema in advance to simplify type access and avoiding type lookups. E.g. references like or .
Note: instances are immutable.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.JSON.JSONSchema
member.summary:
Compatible subset of the JSON Schema specification with some extensions to
enable code generation for various languages
define database schemas declaring its containers, commands and messages
Following extensions are added to the specification:
- used to declare that a type definition extends the given one
- declare the property name used as discriminator
- type should be generated as struct - value type
- type definition is an abstract type
- list of all database messages
- list of all database commands
- name of the property used as primary key
- a map storing the descriptions for enum values
- add meta information to the schema conform to the OpenAPI specification
- mark the property as a relation (aka reference or aka secondary key) to entities in the container named relation
The restriction of are:
A schema property cannot nest anonymous types by "type": "object" with "properties": { ... }.
The property type needs to be a known type like "string", ... or a referenced "$ref" type.
This restriction enables generation of code and types for languages without support of anonymous types.
It also enables concise error messages for validation errors when using .
Note: Arrays and dictionaries are also valid schema properties. E.g.
A valid array property like: { "type": ["array", "null"], "items": { "type": "string" } }
A valid dictionary property like: { "type": "object", "additionalProperties": { "type": "string" } }
These element / value types needs to be a known type like "string", ... or a referenced "$ref" type.
On root level are only "$ref": "..." and "definitions": [...] allowed.

member.name: F:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.JSON.JSONSchema.rootRef
member.summary:
reference to 'main' type definition in to
enable schema urls without fragment suffix like: #/definitions/SomeType

members.member:
Supporting nullable (value type) array elements seems uh - however it is supported. Reasons against:
Application now have to check for null when accessing these types of arrays -> uh
Generated languages have typically no support for custom nullable values types. Common element types like int, byte, ... are typically supported - custom types not.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.Language.Generator
member.summary:
A context class required to be used for all code / schema generators.
Examples available at: Schema unit tests
It contains the configuration for schema generation and the result after schema generation was executed. The main configuration consists of the types to be generated and the file extension for generated files. The result consists of the generated source . The utility method enables writing these files to a folder.
In case of adding an additional code generator which should be part of this project the following requirements must be met:
In case a code generator is added to the library Friflo.Json.Fliox no dependencies to third party libraries must be added. E.g. Serializer libraries to create a specific format (YAML, ...). In case of third party dependencies the implementation requires a separate library. Schema / code generators are forced to use like in .
A code generator must not have any mutable state. All used properties must be readonly immutables.
Avoid virtual methods or interfaces to establish simplicity.
As initial template or need to be used to ensure the resulting generator can be compared to their originals with tools like WinMerge. In particular the methods and their order:
private constructor using as parameter
Helper methods need to be added on the bottom.
The implementation should be small similar to and
The generated files (PocStore and Protocol) must be committed to a folder in 'assets~/Schema' and a lean setup should be added ensuring the generated files are valid / compile successful.

members.member: map of all 's required by the types provided for schema generation
map of all generated files. key: file path
set of generated files and their source content. key: file name
set of files where each type is generated into a separate file
map of all emitted types and their emitted code

member.summary: The generator context class used for specific code generators like . This class contains also general configuration for code generation.
member.param: The schema containing the types used to generate code. The library itself provide and as input schemas.
file extension of the generated files
Optional namespace prefixes used short the namespaces used in the generated files

Optional list of types enabling each listed type is generated in its own file. JSON Schema related tools often expect this schema structure like VSCode. See: [JSON editing in Visual Studio Code] https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/json#_mapping-in-the-user-settings
An optional callback function used to customize the path of generated files. E.g. in case of Java it would be: type => $"{type.Namespace}.{type.Name}" to generate each type in its own file.

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Schema.Validation.NativeValidationSet.AddRootType(System.Type)
member.summary:
is used for optimization.
It create instances for the given and all its dependent types.
The is typically a class type extending FlioxClient - containing all application specific types like entity, command and message types
Adding all instances at once enable reduced memory consumption and high memory locality as only a single is created for a single database schema.

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Transform.Query.QueryConverter.GetMember(System.Linq.Expressions.MemberExpression,Friflo.Json.Fliox.Transform.Query.LambdaCx)
member.summary:
A path of chained fields (members) in C# starts at the root. field_root.field_1. ... .field_leaf In the LINQ expression tree its starts at the leaf (field_n). field_leaf -> ... -> field_1 -> field_root
The root field (member) decide which need to be created. - If the root is a a is created. (*) In this case the root is a lambda argument. - If the root is a a is created from the value return by the leaf field. (*) In this case the root references a variable declared outside the lambda expression. - If the root is null is created from the value return by the leaf field. (*) In this case the root references a static class field / property.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Transform.Tree.JsonAst
member.summary:
Representation of a as a tree of 's.
The 's are enumerated and can be accessed by index using . Root node has index [0]
Its are reused to avoid heap allocations when creating trees from multiple JSON values.
A enables iteration of JSON object members without reading the entire JSON value.
Two instances are used by for efficient patching of a given JSON value with a second JSON patch value.
member.remarks:
JSON example of the indices used at
{ // 0 - root "a": 1 // 1 "b": [ // 2 null // 3 42 // 4 ], "c": { // 5 "c1": true // 6 } }

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Transform.Tree.JsonMerger
member.summary:
Used to merge / patch two given 's efficiently.
Implements [RFC 7386: JSON Merge Patch] https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7386
First it creates two tree representations of both given 's
Both trees are then traversed in step to find their differences. Based on their equalities and differences the resulting JSON value is created.
Reusing a instance typically result in processing without any heap allocations.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Utils.MemoryBuffer
member.summary:
Used to allocate byte arrays used within 's on the heap.
In general it tries to minimize the amount of array allocations.
member.remarks:
Strategy to minimize heap allocations and GC pressure.
don't allocate any array if the is not used
avoid allocation of 'large heap object' 's which required a GEN2 collection
avoid allocated 's having too many unused remaining bytes => quadruple capacity

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Utils.MessageBufferQueue`1
member.summary: A queue used to store messages using double buffering to avoid frequent allocations of byte[] instances for each message.
member.remarks:
To avoid frequent byte[] allocations it utilizes two byte[] buffers.
1. One buffer is used to store the bytes of new messages.
2. The other buffer store the bytes of dequeued messages.
Note Dequeued messages are valid until the next call of
The buffers are swapped when calling .
Note is not thread safe
member.typeparam: Type of the meta data associated to each message. Use if no associated meta data is required
